sections: The big difference between Generative AI and the other buzzword tech of the past few years is that people are finding practical, daily uses for it. I have never knowingly used Web3 or the Metaverse in my work ‚Äì but I do use generative AI to illustrate my posts.

In the last couple of weeks, I‚Äôve come a journalist using a personal, paid ChatGPT account in their work and another worrying that their particular skills are no longer needed. I‚Äôve seen examples of students using LLMs to generate essays (and those are just the ones that were caught‚Ä¶).
I‚Äôm experimenting with a Slack bot that claims to assist in your SEO work. Generative AI is here, with clear use cases that make sense to ordinary people.
That‚Äôs what those other trendy technologies never managed.

The last time I remember something happening quite this quickly was social media in the late 2000s. Back then, too many publishers were too slow to adopt sensible guidelines for their staff, leading to some unfortunate errors ‚Äî and consequent reputation damage. Indeed, I‚Äôd argue that our slowness then to set boundaries has led to some of the trust erosion we‚Äôre seeing now.
Watching journalists tear chuncks off each other in a partisan way on Twitter is doing nothing for our reputation for impartiality and trustworthiness.
And so, I‚Äôm bloomin‚Äô delighted to see some larger publishers getting ahead of this. Chris Moran
published their first pass at some a few weeks ago.
Where are you on getting yours sorted?

This is a serious question: if we're not ruthlessly transparent with our readers about if, how and where we're using AI, we're setting ourselves up for another serious decline in our already shaky trust levels. It's why one major point of similarity in the
appoaches is transparancy. Here's the relevant par from the

We will be transparent, within the FT and with our readers. All newsroom experimentation will be recorded in an internal register, including, to the extent possible, the use of third-party providers who may be using the tool. Training for our journalists on the use of generative AI for story discovery will be provided through a series of masterclasses.
If you have staff already using AI ‚Äî you need to find out, and soon. Whatever you do, don't discourage experimentation. But make sure it's clearly tagged as such to the readers.
The Reuters Digital News Report controversy
, until I head some of my colleagues at City discussing it earlier in the week:

Nobel peace laureate Maria Ressa has claimed Oxford University‚Äôs leading journalism institute is publishing flawed research that puts journalists and independent outlets at risk, particularly in the global south.

Its findings include rating Rappler ‚Äì the outlet Ressa co-founded, and whose work was cited in her Nobel prize nomination ‚Äì the least trusted media outlet on a list of those surveyed in the Philippines.

The reason, of course, it‚Äôs so untrusted is a long-running disinformation campaign to discredit it. And while the report acknowledges that, Ressa‚Äôs argument is that the finding can still be used against them by the government.
published a response on its website

Alan Rusbridger, Chair of the Reuters Institute‚Äôs Steering Committee, says: ‚ÄúWe deplore abuse against Maria Ressa and misrepresentation of our research. The Institute has reviewed the methodology with our country partners and Advisory Board. We believe it is robust. We have taken steps to mitigate abuse, push back against it, and will continue to do so‚Äù.

I don‚Äôt have a lot to add here. There are some situations where I know it‚Äôs better for me to shut up and listen. I‚Äôm not a research academic. I‚Äôm not a journalist working under life-threatening conditions. There are people much better equipped to navigate these complexities than me.
I know, I know. Profound failure as a pundit‚Ä¶

What went wrong for the internet‚Äôs original fact check site?

If you‚Äôve been on the internet long enough, you‚Äôll have used Snopes. In the late 90s and early 2000s, it was the go-to site for debunking viral email chain letters, and then their reincarnated form on Facebook. But, even as misinformation has surged on the old interwebs, Snopes has slowly faded from relevance.

This impulse to outwit and rile up folks felt weirdly at odds with the good faith and empathy you‚Äôd expect from someone in his business. In 2016, for example, Mikkelson kidded with Green on Slack that a man named Jeff Zarronandia was his best hire. ‚ÄúModel employee,‚Äù Green replied, according to screenshots. Mikkelson had made up Zarronandia a year before to troll the conservatives who insisted that Snopes was biased toward liberals. But as Snopes sought to level up, Green, then the director of business development, told Mikkelson that he thought they needed to ‚Äúclean up our loose ends.‚Äù That didn‚Äôt happen, and Zarronandia was outed as an alt in a BuzzFeed expos√© by the reporter Dean Sterling Jones.
Too many of the early internet successes were run by people with great ideas ‚Äî but without anything like the skill needed to manage a huge success. And so things spiral into ever increasing chaos.
